This was played in our Club Championship. Although Steve is not in our club he very kindly stepped in to make the numbers up when someone dropped out. As the player with the lower grade he had choice of colours, and opted for black.
Last o f the doubleheader

Up front I should mention that I am "old school" with regard to annotations. Back in the day they were written as though by a third person who analyzed the game impartially; evidently a personal journal by one of the players is the modern approach, probably because engines are now of sufficient strength to provide meaningful "comments". This is my first attempt with the new style.

Commentary: This move is off book. I read a chess magazine once extolling the virtues of "crustacean," where one player opens with the rook pawns. I think most players regard this advance as having little merit. Though as a springboard for an assault on a potential black castle it might be worth considering. White won't want to castle king's side, though. In this game neither side castles.

History (PGN): d4 Nf6
Commentary: Accelerated London system. Resembling the Colle System, white develops the Bishop to Bc1-f4 the hallmark of the London. The orthodox move order has always been on the 3rd move, e.g., 1. d4 2. Nf3 3. Bf4 to what ever Black plays. The Accelerated London develops the bishop on move 2. I'm not a Londoner so I'm not going to write the pros and cons of The orthodox London vs the accelerated London system and how it is meant to deal with Black's moves. I just know it's really in vogue right now and a hot opening for White because Magnus Carlsen has played it. I will add black will face a blunted King's Indian Defense if both sides were to develop their own system, i.e., The london system vs the King's Indian Defense. For example, 1. d4...Nf6 2. Nf3...g6 3. Bf4...Bg7 4. e3...d6 5. Be2..0-0 6. 0-0.

Commentary: This is the whole point of this line, opening the h-file for my queen to come with check, which will force Black to give up his queen to avoid mate. Believe it or not, engines have difficulty spotting this idea at first, and suggest taking the draw by repetition with 15.Qc1 Kh7 16.Qc2+ etc.

Before i went to the match which was 70 miles away from Home in Milton keynes and its 50 roundabouts (no exageration) I had prepared for a number of usual openings and was gutted to find this as i was out of prep on move 1. Not a great start lol.

Commentary: It is a natural temptation to just take f2. Who doesn't dream about doing that? Or is it just me? Anyway, the point of exchanging the pawns was so that the e4 pawn is now undefended, and can be safely taken by the knight, without fear of being banished. Probably unnecessary precaution on its own, but it also lets the queens have a direct confrontation, which might also not be relevant now, but could come in handy later, for an exchange.

I went into a deep think regarding 19. Ng5 (which my engine actually claims is the best move). Over the board I calculated: 19. Ng5 Bxd1 20.Nxf7+ Kxh7 21.Nxd6 Nxf1 22.Nxe8 Rxe8 23.Kxf1 which leaves me with three pawns for a bishop (two connected passers). While I thought this was probably okay, I didn't trust myself over the board and was worried I would miss a tactic or line. So instead I played it safe. The problem is I played it safe in a bad way, moving my bishop to c2 rather than b1. Oh well!

This game was originally a Sicilian, in which I made an early decision (move 12) to go for an endgame. This style of play is unusual for me, and outside my comfort zone. In the end the game was won, and was won in exactly the way I envisaged. But this is not to say that I forced this outcome. I would welcome comments from more experienced players about the idea itself and the implementation.

Commentary: This is a mistake. In his defense it is hard for him to develop any of his pieces here. So he is preparing to bring out either his queen's bishop or rook. His other pieces need to stay where they are to defend his pinned bishop. He should have moved his king to break the pin on his bishop. Of course the bishop would still be pinned by my bishop, but he could exchange bishops and get rid of the pin permanently. This requires foregoing castling which he is apparently unwilling to do.

Commentary: It says I blundered here and gave Coldbrew mate in 14 moves. I'm not sure I've ever played anyone who can string a game out 14 moves to mate from this position... The rest of this game is what the engine classifies as a series of blunders on both sides, but I'm not sure any commentary matters much past move 37 or so since I think the best it said I could expect was to be at -60 and surrounded by white's pawns. I resigned at 42 because I just didn't see how it was possible to stop all of his pawns, so drawing it out seemed unsportsmanlike. I congratulate my opponent and appreciate his and his team captain's willingness to match me up with a much higher rated player.

Hi everyone! In this game, a king is caught in the centre and that unlucky king's opponent then takes advantage of the situation by using a pawn to smash open some lines onto the uncastled king. A certain queen hovers around like a vulture and then descends on it. But whose king ends up in Old Matey's shadow and cannot escape? Read on and see.

History (PGN): e4 c5 f4 d6 d4 cxd4 Bc4
Commentary: The whole point of pawn to f4 in the King's Gambit is to clear the isle and get that pawn OUT OF THE WAY. Anyone who has used King's Gambit as white knows how FAST any game can become terribly complicated.......

This was an extremely lucky win. I made a mistake in the opening, and was punished for it, losing a pawn. he then sacrificed a bishop for two pawns and a raging attack. He missed some winning chances, and finally I was knight for pawn up in the ending.

The only weakness here is that the d7 bishop cannot quickly occupy the a8-h1 diagonal.

After seeing a video about the Englund Gambit, featuring a particularly nasty trap, I wanted to give this a try. Despite the first move being considered one of the weakest replies black can have. The resulting game was one I particularly enjoyed, although I cannot in good conscience credit the opening for that.

When this tournament game started, my opponent was a good 100 points north of my rating. If I'd won he would be the highest ranked player I had beaten for some considerable time. The game started when my confidence was high. I had just completed reading Sierawans Strategy book which for me consolidated and added to some of the ideas I had already and which resulted in my rating skyrocketing by about 100 points to the highest its ever been, so I was optimistic. The tournament itself was meant to be KGA but very few games started like that. this is Van't Kruijs opening which I'm not familiar with

Hi everyone! It is high time I did an annotation. Haven't done any since my cancer diagnosis (had my 3rd round of chemo today). Feeling a bit more up to doing a few more. This game meanders into the late middlegame with both sides playing solidly. I try another mating attack but it gets rebuffed. This game ends with me trying to checkmate him with Glenda and my rook but he uses his queen as a get out of jail free card and Henry cannot avoid her checks - sssss and double ssss. Well, we will all get to see how this comes about.

If White takes exd5, now I have an open file against his king, and with existing pressure from deployed pieces it creates some trouble. Remember, to launch attacks you need pieces. Do not be so quick to trade, as getting your pieces to work in harmony and applying layered threats and pressures is what chess is all about.

History (PGN): e4 c5 Nf3 d6 d4 cxd4 Nxd4 Nf6 Nc3 Nc6 Be2
Commentary: This is the Boleslavsky Variation, named after Isaac Boleslavsky. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isaac_Boleslavsky I create the "Boleslavsky hole" on d5 where white can perhaps manoeuvre a piece to. Black also has a weak pawn on d6. But in return black has central control and possible play on the black squares. Black may also at some stage be able to play d6-d5 getting rid of these weaknesses. I was inspired to adopt this partly by a game in the book "The Road to Chess Mastery" by Max Euwe. The variation is also mentioned in a "Think like a Grandmaster" by Alexander Kotov. I studied both of them in the 1970s as a teenager.

Commentary: Conclusions: one of the startling things that came to me was that one of my hidden advantages seemed to have been this unassuming pawn structure. It seems weird, ugly even, but the e3/f2 pawns made sure that throughout my hedge over the king could not be penetrated quickly enough. It is so odd to think that this might have been one of the factors that allowed me to keep attacking, have time for missing things, and still keep at it. Well the other factor was my spare bishop of course, but I did not get to use it as much as I liked, until the very last moments of the game. The other thought: even without truly understanding the London, I find it easier to play it in average and survive against most setups, even ones that trade the dark squared bishop, or KID or the Anti London c5. Of course I would probably prefer something less commital against even stronger players, but still, it can be fun.

History (PGN): d4 d5 Bf4 Nc6 e3 Nf6 f3 Bf5 h4 Nb4 Na3 e6
Commentary: Advancing pawns almost always need to be blocked or threatened. Once they are in your side of the board, they are dangerous. So when I'm playing well, in this case I stop, and ask, "What happens if that pawn advances again next turn? a6. 1) I take it, weakening my possible castle, or weakening my pawn attack. He can then even bring his bishop to a6, and cause more weakness. 2) I leave it. Same result. It weakens everything. Pawn structure is critical. I'll exchange a bishop or knight almost 100% of the time if it means pawns that are back to back, and can't support each other. I'll make exchanges all the time if it means a pawn gets isolated. Once it is, I muster the troops to attack that little pawn. Maybe your opponent will need to defend the lonely pawn, leaving him vulnerable elsewhere.

I felt I should annotate this game for reasons that I hope will become clear. This game was a part of the 199th GK tournament. Round 1 of the tournament began when my rating was very much in the ascendancy, so much so that by the end of round 1 I was moved up to the next level! While I understand why this happens, in my case it felt rather unfair moving from the upper realms of the group to the lower ones of the next group, this wasn't helped as my rating began its inevitable and eventually long slide in the wrong direction. This game was against the highest ranked opponent of the group who was rated over 1900. My rating peak was in the lower 1700's and I was just about comfortable there. Playing someone rated this highly felt optimistic to say the least, particularly as my rating had dipped below 1600 for the first time in a while and was still descending. Needless to say I lost 5 of the 6 games and there was only this one left where I had any chance whatsoever of regaining some of my lost pride. The game begins with my usual opening as white. Analysis can be found at https://gameknot.com/analyze-board.pl?bd=31295397

After 5...Nxe4 6.d4 exd4 7.Re1 d5 8.Nxd4 Bd6 9.Nxc6 Bxh2ch ... and now: [A] 10.Kxh2 Qh4ch 11.Kg1 Qxf2ch 12.Kh1 Qh4ch etc with a repetition; [B] 10.Kf1(?) Qh4 11.Nd4ch c6 12.Be3 Bg4 - and Black has an edge [C] 10.Kh1(!) Qh4 11.Rxe4ch dxe4 12.Qd8ch Qxd8 13.Nxd8ch Kxd8 - and White has the edge.

History (PGN): d4 d5 Nf3 Nf6 c4 dxc4 Nc3 a6
Commentary: INSTRUCTIVE ERROR #1 White has chosen (by transposition) Queen's Gambit Accepted (ECO D24). ALL opening gambits sacrifice some material early on to open lines of attack, yet here White needlessly makes a defensive move. The move is not completely without redeeming value -- Black plays ...Bg4 in many variations of this opening -- but it is certainly anti-thematic, and in fact dooms White to play from behind until Black stubs his toe on Moves 49-52. 5.e4, establishing control of the center and attacking Black's advanced pawn, is the most popular continuation, followed by 5.a4, which prevents 5...b5.

Hi everyone! It is not often I give away the outcome of a game in the title, but because this game will go in a themed thread on Walking the Walk & Learning to Run, I feel it is necessary. The player who is at a disadvantage (either threatened with # on the move) or behind on material usually instigates the perpetual check. But who was the instigator of the perpetual? Read on and find out.

Commentary: Completing development of the minor pieces - with a tempo, as the White f-pawn is pinned. A nice intermezzo, but Black could have played 12...Bd6 at once, leaving the 'off-side' knight looking a little sheepish.

This is is a friendly between team mates. In it features textbook play against an early Bc4 in the Sicilian. Also white develops his pieces in suboptimal squares. As a result, Black is able to carve out so much space that white had no where to go. Yet his defense was solid until he just simply got swarmed.

I think I am finally learning a bitter lesson from my loss against The Dentist many years ago when I failed to find any similar counterplay when we both castled on opposite sides and succumbed to passivitis and a 3 pawn loss in the endgame. I The Black Queen will not make that mistake again!
